slides.text:
HYALINE:
articular surface covered in a thin layer of cartilage

JOINT CAVITY filled with synovial fluid:
provides lubrication and nutrition to the cartilage

SYNOVIAL MEMBRANE:
Sleeve of delicate cartilage attached around the periphery of the articular surface - contains SYNOVIAL FLUID

FIBROUS CAPSULE:
Externally strengthens the synovial membrane

pages.title: Diagram to show a typical synovial joint

slides.text:
OSTEOCHONDROSIS:
young animal e.g. Great Dane and Newfoundland

Insensitive - no nerve supply and is avascular - disease can progress a long way before there are clinical signs

CARTILAGE-HYALINE: 
-Translucent glossy surface 
-White tinge with blue in young 
-Yellows with age
-Shock absorbing 
-Smooth surface

pages.title: High powered diagram of the articular surface

slides.text: e.g. TEMPOROMANDIBULAR JOINT (Much bigger in herbivores)

ARTICULAR DISC:
divides joint into 2

pages.title: Diagram to show articular discs and menisci (meniscus)

slides.text:
Discs and menisci - hyaline and fibrocartilage
FUNCTION:
-Provide congruence (eg femur is curved and tabia is not therefore incongruent) for incompatible joint surfaces.
-Resolve complex movements into simpler components
-Provide some shock absorption
Joint cavity not completely divided

pages.title: Discs and menisci

slides.text:
E.g. proximal interphalangeal joint
-Movement is flexion and extension

COLLATERAL LIGAMENTS:
powerful, strong (medial and lateral) restrict the movement of flexion and extension

pages.title: Hinge Joint

slides.text:
E.g. femorotibial joint of the stifle

COMMON AXIS:
movement is unilateral about an axis common to the two condyles

pages.title: Condylar Joint

slides.text:
E.g. radiocarpal joint
-Movement in two planes

pages.title: Ellipsoidal Joint

slides.text: E.g. hip joint - large range of movement

ARTICULAR LABRUM:
FIBROCARTILAGINOUS LIP
extends joint but allows for greater flexibility

pages.title: Ball and socket joint

slides.text: E.g. distal interphalangeal joint

DORSAL ELASTIC LIGAMENT:
keeps claws retracted

Two surfaces each maximally concave in one direction and convex in a perpendicular direction 
-Biaxial joint
-Movement is flexion and extension with some rotation

pages.title: Saddle joint

slides.text:
NERVE FIBRES:
-Pain
-Proprioception (tells you where joint is in space and time)

pages.title: Blood and nerve supply to the joint capsule

slides.text:
Cartilage:
elastic, covered by skin

HELIX:
many blood vessels on the helix

ANNULAR CARTILAGE:
through which the auricle or external ear is attached to the skull
CUTANEOUS POUCH:
allows for some flexibility

[1]: PRETRAGIC NOTCH:
important surgical landmark

[2]: INTERTRAGIC NOTCH:
important surgical landmark

TYMPANIC MEMBRANE:
closes the external auditory meatus

[1]: TRAGUS

[2]: ANTITRAGUS

pages.title: External ear of the dog

slides.text:
Cheeks:
lateral boundary of oral cavity

labels.text: Caudal boundary of nasal and oral cavities
Position of soft palate during swallowing and vomiting

slides.text:
NOSTRILS:
rostral boundary of nasal cavity

SOFT PALATE:
during breathing

HARD PALATE:
dorsal boundary of oral cavity

LIPS:
rostral boundary of oral cavity

VENTRAL BOUNDARY:
floor of oral cavity

pages.title: Diagram to show a sagittal section of the dog head

slides.text:
INNERVATION FACIAL NERVE
VIIth CRANIAL NERVE

PAROTIDOAURICULARIS:
paired, deeper than platysma

ZYGOMATICO AURICULARIS:
paired

SPHINCTER - COLLI PROFUNDUS:
caudal part, paired

FRONTALIS:
paired

ORBICULARIS OCULI:
paired, lies within eyelid

ORBICULARIS ORIS:
single, lies within lips

PLATYSMA:
paired, thin, extends from the neck to the lips

RETRACTOR ANGULI OCULI:
paired

ZYGOMATICUS:
paired

LEVATOR NASOLABIALIS:
paired

HELICIS:
paired

pages.title: Diagram to show the muscles of facial expression

slides.text:
FACIAL LYMPH NODE:
not always present

[1]: LINGUAL VEIN

[2]: LINGUOFACIAL VEIN

[3]: JUGULAR VEIN

[4]: MAXILLARY VEIN

[5]: Mandibular salivary gland:
ducts open in floor of mouth
Monastic part of sublingual gland:
ducts open in floor of mouth

[1]: AURICULAR NERVE

[2]: AURICULOPALPEBRAL NERVE

[3]: PALPEBRAL NERVE

[4]: DORSAL BUCCAL:
branch of facial nerve

[5]: VENTRAL BUCCAL:
branch of facial nerve

[6]: INFRAORBITAL NERVE:
sensory in muzzle, branch of TRIGEMINAL NERVE Vth CRANIAL NERVE
INFRAORBITAL FORAMEN:
branches of facial nerve, VIIth cranial nerve, motor nerve

[7]: PAROTID SALIVARY GLAND:
two located at base of external ear

[8]: DUCT OF P. S. GLAND:
is superficial and opens in the oral cavity opposite the upper carnassial tooth, can be redirected to lateral eye to overcome persistent dry eye

pages.title: Diagram to show superficial structures of the head

slides.text: Three pairs to close the jaws, one pair to open

[1]: TEMPORALIS MUSCLE:
closed jaw attaches to coronoid process of mandible

[2]: DIGASTRIC MUSCLE:
only one belly in the dog, opens the jaw in herbivores where there are two bellies

[3]: MASSETER MUSCLE:
closes and retracts the jaw, more significant in herbivores as aids lateral movement

[4]: PTERYGOID MUSCLE:
closes the jaws arises from pterygoid bone and inserts on the medial aspect of the mandible

[5]: ORBITAL LIGAMENT

pages.title: Diagram to shot the muscles of mastication (all paired)

slides.text:
[1]: STYLOHYOID BONE

[2]: BASIHYOID BONE

[3]: THYROHYOID BONE

STYLOGLOSSUS MUSCLE:
lateral

HYOGLOSSUS MUSCLE:
root of tongue

MYLOHYOID MUSCLE:
mylohyoideus

GENIOHYOID MUSCLE:
geniohyoideus

8: GENIOGLOSSUS:
midline muscle

MANDIBLE

Symphysis

pages.title: Diagram to show the extrinsic muscles of the tongue (all paired)

slides.text:
Functions:
-Provide attachment for both the tongue (rostrally) and the larynx (caudally)
-Plays a role in both swallowing and breathing (breaks during strangulation)

[1]: THYROHYOID articulation (cartilaginous joint)

[2]: THYROHYOID BONE:
paired

[3]: BASIHYOID BONE:
single

[4]: KERATOHYOID BONE:
paired

[5]: EPIHYOID BONE:
paired

[6]: SYNOVIAL JOINT

[7]: STYLOHYOID BONE:
paired

[8]: Cartilaginous joint - TYMPANOHYOID articulation

pages.title: Diagram to shot the Hyoid apparatus of the dog

slides.text:
-Tendons of insertion of the supraspinatus, infraspinatus and subscapularis muscles act as active collateral ligaments
-Vital role in stabilising shoulder joint
-GLENOHUMERAL LIGAMENTS: thickening of joint caps, relatively weak
-movement is mainly FLEXION and EXTENSION

[1]: SUPRASPINOUS FOSSA

[2]: SPINE OF THE SCAPULA

[3]: SCAPULA

[4]: INFRASPINOUS FOSSA

[5]: GREATER TUBERCLE OF THE HUMERUS

[6]: GLENOID CAVITY

[7]: HEAD OF THE HUMERUS

[2]: Tendon of the SUPRASPINATUS muscle

[3]: LATERAL GLENOHUMERAL LIGAMENT

[4]: Tendon of insertion of the INFRASPINATUS muscle

pages.title: Shoulder joint of the dog (Dorsal)

slides.text:
[1]: RADIAL FOSSA

[2]: MEDIAL EPICONDYLE

[3]: ANCONEAL PROCESS

[4]: OLECRANON OF THE ULNA

[5]: LATERAL EPICONDYLE

OLECRANON LIGAMENT:
medial wall of radial fossa and olecranon (prevents extensive flexion)

pages.title: Right elbow of the dog (caudal aspect of the joint)

slides.text:
OBLIQUE LIGAMENT:
prevents excessive extension (beyond 180 degrees)

[1]: MEDIAL COLLATERAL LIGAMENT

[2]: Tendon of insertion of biceps brachii

[3]: ANNULAR LIGAMENT:
holds the tendons in place across the joint but also allows the rotation of the radius

pages.title: Right elbow of the dog (cranial aspect)

slides.text:
MEDIAL COLLATERAL LIGAMENT:
along with the lateral collateral ligament, limits medial and lateral movement

labels.text: Tendon of insertion of biceps brachii

pages.title: Right elbow of the dog (medial aspect)

slides.text:
ACCESSORY CARPAL BONE:
non weight-bearing

DISTAL ROW:
RADIOCARPAL BONE
INTERMEDIO CARPAL BONE

1ST DIGIT:
non weight-bearing due to claw

ANTEBRACHIAL CARPAL JOINT:
has the greatest movement

MIDDLE CARPAL JOINT

CARPOMETACARPAL JOINT

pages.title: Bones and joints at the carpus

slides.text:
FIBROUS JOINT CAPSULE:
-thickened on palmar aspect to from PALMAR CARPAL LIGAMENT
-encloses all three joints
-collagenous/cartilaginous - provides smooth surface for passage of flexor tendons, blood vessels and nerves

FIBROUS JOINT CAPSULE:
-forms exterior retinaculum
-surrounds extensor tendon

ANTEBRACHIAL CARPAL JOINT:
-has its own synovial membrane
-50 to 60 degrees of FLEXION

MIDDLE CARPAL JOINT:
-15 degrees of FLEXION
-shares a synovial membrane and joints communicate

CARPOMETACARPAL JOINT:
-5 degrees of FLEXION

pages.title: Sagittal section of carpus

slides.text:
ARTICULAR PROCESSES:
carry the cranial and caudal articular surfaces or FOVEA

DORSAL SPINE:
muscle attachment forms from fused laminae - failure of fusion gives SPINA BIFIDA 

TRANSVERSE PROCESS:
-extend laterally from the junction of the pedicle and the lamina

VERTEBRAL FORAMEN:
in series - vertebral canal which contains the spinal cord

PEDICLE:
forms sides of the vertebral arch

BODY OF THE VERTEBRA:
-main bulk
-cranial and caudal surface which are nearly flat for the attachment of the fibrocartilaginous discs

slides.text:
[1]: CRANIAL ARTICULAR FOVEA or SURFACE

for the tubercle of the ribs - or a reduced transverse process

[3]: CRANIAL COSTAL FOVEA:
articulation with the head of the rib

[4]: CAUDAL COSTAL FOVEA:
articulation with the head of the rib

INTERVERTEBRAL FORAMEN:
spinal nerve

slides.text:

-protects the disc from prolapse into vertebral foramen
-prolapse very rare in thoracic region due to this ligament

[2]: COSTAL FOVEA

synovial joint

[4]: Isohal part

[5]: Represent straps of cartilage present in young animal - disappear with age
